DEVELOPMENT DIARY


Jan 2001
At last! We've got some screenshots for your perusal...



24 July 2000
Magic. It is - after all - a game based on magic, but how to make the system worth something with a limited graphic set, and how to make it more than just another set of options - which worked so well for the books.

On top of this, how do we keep it fresh?

So - the magic system we have…without giving too much away…is component based. You play through the game amassing components. Then it is up to the player to work out which components work with which. Some are obvious - a lot are less so.

The other difference is in the method of casting spells. In the book it cost STAM. In this version of the game - where possible - the player loses STAM by sacrificing blood. This gives us a gothic edge to our magic system.

The joy of the component system is in its utter freedom. We can set up items for the player to use in later books, as well as provide an enormously open system for players to create their own spells.


30 June 2000
So - the first entry in a diary that will stop everyone saying "You've got such a cool job!". The basic starting point is, of course, the books. We have a really great game mechanic for combat and plotting a path through an adventure...if you have a book. Both Steve and I wanted something that would take advantage of the WAP technology while neatly avoiding some of its drawbacks. This was a long task in itself. We wanted a graphical combat system, an animated magic system and, as much as possible, a graphical front end. And so we faced every problem known to WAP - minimal processing on the phone, graphics stored in cache, the trade-off between connecting often for small amounts of data or less often and dragging down loads of data.

At the end I think we came up with a good set of options - a great interactive combat system, a magic system that builds throughout the game, and our graphical front end. How this all looks I'll cover as this diary goes on and we look at different sections of the game. However, now plot additions and new areas are demanding my attention. And that's your cliffhanger. In the next section I'll look at the enhancements we're making to the game for play on a Mobile Phone.
